author: Richard Hartley-Parkinson
title: Millions of UK eggs to lose their free-range status

organizations.name: department for environment, food and rural affairs

text:
Farmers have been ordered to keep their hens inside (Picture: Getty) Millions of UK eggs are to temporarily lose their free-range status after farmers were forced to keep hens inside barns to limit the spread of bird flu.
An avian influenza prevention zone was declared on December 6, forcing owners to keep poultry and captive birds indoors or to take steps to separate them from wild birds.
Teachers in fight with head filmed chanting 'she's getting sacked in the morning' Under EU legislation, eggs from birds which have been housed for more than 12 weeks cannot be marketed as free range.
Defra, the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, has advised that it is adopting a more targeted approach as of today, with the majority of producers in England able to let their birds outside again providing they observe strict disease prevention measures.
Producers in Scotland and Wales will also need to carry out similar risk assessments.
Eggs from birds that have been housed for more than 12 weeks cannot be marketed as free range (Picture: Getty) Areas close to large inland or coastal bodies of water, where significant numbers of wild birds collect, are deemed higher risk, so compulsory housing or total netting will continue to be mandatory.
Defra said around 75% of poultry keepers will be unaffected, but where birds are housed rather than netted, eggs and some poultry from them will no longer be classed as free range.
Student who faced being deported before completing degree saved just hours before her flight A Defra spokesman said: ‘Strict disease control measures are currently in place to reduce the risk of the spread of avian flu in the UK, which means some birds are being kept inside for their welfare. Where birds are being kept inside, we have advised retailers that products must be clearly labelled so shoppers can make an informed choice.
‘After February 28, under current proposals, the majority of producers in England will be able to let birds outside provided they observe strict disease prevention measures, and we do not anticipate significant disruption to the supply of free-range eggs. Producers in the higher risk areas could still market their eggs as free range, provided they use netting and meet other free range criteria.’
The British Egg Industry Council (BEIC), which represents more than 95% of UK free-range egg production, said that although some free-range hens will be allowed back outside this week, some farmers will choose to temporarily keep their hens housed to protect them from the continued risk of avian influenza.
It said all members’ free-range egg packs will temporarily carry stickers from tomorrow, informing consumers that the eggs have been laid by hens currently kept in barns, to create a level playing field for producers.
There will also be signs near where eggs are sold highlighting this and the freerangeinfo.com website has been set up.
BEIC chief executive Mark Williams said: ‘The need to change labelling of free-range egg packs after 12 weeks is an EU requirement. However, these are all still free-range hens but some are temporarily housed to protect them from bird flu.
‘Free range producers still incur the same costs for land and staff while birds are housed, and in many cases are facing increased costs for additional biosecurity.
‘We need to avoid a potential ‘postcode lottery’ whereby individual farmers could be penalised if they have chosen to temporarily continue to keep their hens inside.
‘Therefore all of our members, supported by retailers, have taken the decision to label all free-range eggs, to help protect the future of the British free range sector.’
He added: ‘Our research shows that consumers are supportive of farmers putting birds’ health first and 80% are happy to continue to pay the same price, or more, for eggs from free-range flocks temporarily housed inside.’
